[dvergin] 2004-01-26
In response to [BazB]'s questions below:
[Editor Requests] is a remnant of the early days at Perl Monks. It is not nearly as important as it once was. For example: folks can edit their own root nodes and much of the load originally handled through [Editor Requests] is now taken care of promptly and effectively by the consideration process.

Wanting a niche where I could contribute to the good of the order, I stumbled across [Editor Requests] some time back at a point when there were several outstanding requests. It seemed a nice place to be of help, so in the clever guise of the ER Hobbit, I quietly began handling the items posted there.

It has been a long time since the ER load was very heavy. And it is even lighter recently since people can edit their own root nodes. So there isn't much reason for more than one person to watch the queue (if that person checks regularly -- I have a script that checks for me every 20 minutes whenever I am on line). Still, if you see an unanswered request there and want to handle it, go ahead. Don't worry that it will plunge my life into meaningless oblivion. ;-)

ER items do not automatically appear in [Nodes Requiring Editing]. Sometimes I log on to discover an ER item that has already been separately submitted for consideration and handled. Other times, I handle an ER request by submitting a node for consideration myself.

FWIW: A few thoughts regarding having ER items automatically appear in [Nodes Requiring Editing].

  1. Doing so would effectively give *all* participants the right to submit items to NRE -- as you know, this power is currently reserved for monks of a certain level (level 5?) or above. Note that while ER is intended to be for requests regarding one's own nodes, this is not programatically enforced.
  2. Related point: not every request in ER is appropriate fodder for NRE. Both in my experience and in the 200 or so answered ER items that were there when I began service there, it regularly happens that the appropriate response is advice to the petitioner, action a bit different from the actual request, or an explanation to the petitioner that their request is impractical or against policy.
  3. My impression is that in practice, the ER process often involves more hand-holding than Consideration -- specifically, if a NRE request is denied, there is generally no explanation to the petitioner -- if an ER request is denied, I try to provide a friendly and helpful explanation to the petitioner.
  4. It is not uncommon for an ER item to be much longer than NRE notes are. The layout and flow of the NRE page might suffer.

Regards,
TERH
